log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)=log‚Å°œÄK‚Å¢(ùê≥K)=log‚Å°pK‚àí1‚Å¢(ùê≥K‚àí1)‚àílog‚Å°|det(d‚Å¢fKd‚Å¢zK‚àí1)|=log‚Å°pK‚àí2‚Å¢(ùê≥K‚àí2)‚àílog‚Å°|det(d‚Å¢fK‚àí1d‚Å¢zK‚àí2)|‚àílog‚Å°|det(d‚Å¢fKd‚Å¢zK‚àí1)|=‚ãØ=log‚Å°p0‚Å¢(z0)‚àí‚àëi=1Klog‚Å°|det(d‚Å¢fid‚Å¢zi‚àí1)|.ùëùùê±subscriptùúãùêæsubscriptùê≥ùêæsubscriptùëùùêæ1subscriptùê≥ùêæ1ùëësubscriptùëìùêæùëësubscriptùëßùêæ1subscriptùëùùêæ2subscriptùê≥ùêæ2ùëësubscriptùëìùêæ1ùëësubscriptùëßùêæ2ùëësubscriptùëìùêæùëësubscriptùëßùêæ1‚ãØsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëß0superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæùëësubscriptùëìùëñùëësubscriptùëßùëñ1\begin{split}\log p(\mathbf{x})=\log\pi_{K}(\mathbf{z}_{K})&=\log p_{K-1}(% \mathbf{z}_{K-1})-\log\left|\det\left({\frac{df_{K}}{dz_{K-1}}}\right)\right|% \\ &=\log p_{K-2}(\mathbf{z}_{K-2})-\log\left|\det\left({\frac{df_{K-1}}{dz_{K-2}% }}\right)\right|-\log\left|\det\left({\frac{df_{K}}{dz_{K-1}}}\right)\right|\\ &=\cdots\\ &=\log p_{0}(z_{0})-\sum_{i=1}^{K}\log\left|\det\left({\frac{df_{i}}{dz_{i-1}}% }\right)\right|.\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ) = roman_log italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL = roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log | roman_det ( divide start_ARG italic_d italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) | end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log | roman_det ( divide start_ARG italic_d italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) | - roman_log | roman_det ( divide start_ARG italic_d italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) | end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = ‚ãØ end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log | roman_det ( divide start_ARG italic_d italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) | . end_CELL end_ROW (2.20)

Finally, the objective of training for a generative model is maximizing the likelihood of a training set, ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, as follows:

‚Ñí‚Å¢(ùíü)=‚àí1|ùíü|‚Å¢‚àëx‚ààùíülog‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±).‚Ñíùíü1ùíüsubscriptùë•ùíüùëùùê±\begin{split}\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D})=-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}|}\sum_{x\in% \mathcal{D}}\log p(\mathbf{x})\end{split}.start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_L ( caligraphic_D ) = - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_D | end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ) end_CELL end_ROW . (2.21)

In practice, there are two conditions to consider when deciding proper functions for normalizing flows. The first condition is that by definition, the functions should be invertible. Also, computing the Jacobian determinant should be feasible since usually computing the Jacobian of functions and computing the determinant are both computationally expensive. As a result, properly defining the function fùëìfitalic_f is the key to normalizing flows.

There are several feasible functions from previous studies that satisfy the constraints: linear function (Rezende and Mohamed, 2015), 1√ó1111\times 11 √ó 1 convolution (Kingma and Dhariwal, 2018), and affine coupling layer (Dinh et¬†al., 2014; Durkan et¬†al., 2019). In this paper, we introduce the affine coupling layer as an example since this is one of the widely used forms due to its ability to deal with high-dimensional data such as image and sound. The affine coupling layer from Dinh et¬†al. (2016) can be formulated as follows:

ùê≤1:d=ùê±1:dùê≤d+1:D=ùê±d+1:D‚äôexp‚Å°(s‚Å¢(ùê±1:d))+t‚Å¢(ùê±1:d),subscriptùê≤:1ùëësubscriptùê±:1ùëësubscriptùê≤:ùëë1ùê∑direct-productsubscriptùê±:ùëë1ùê∑ùë†subscriptùê±:1ùëëùë°subscriptùê±:1ùëë\begin{split}&\mathbf{y}_{1:d}=\mathbf{x}_{1:d}\\ &\mathbf{y}_{d+1:D}=\mathbf{x}_{d+1:D}\odot\exp{\left(s(\mathbf{x}_{1:d})% \right)}+t(\mathbf{x}_{1:d}),\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 : italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 : italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚äô roman_exp ( italic_s ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) + italic_t ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL end_ROW (2.22)

where ùê≤1:dsubscriptùê≤:1ùëë\mathbf{y}_{1:d}bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the first dùëëditalic_d elements of ùê≤ùê≤\mathbf{y}bold_y, ùê≤d+1:Dsubscriptùê≤:ùëë1ùê∑\mathbf{y}_{d+1:D}bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 : italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the rest of ùê≤ùê≤\mathbf{y}bold_y, ùê±1:dsubscriptùê±:1ùëë\mathbf{x}_{1:d}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the first dùëëditalic_d elements of ùê±ùê±\mathbf{x}bold_x, ùê±d+1:Dsubscriptùê±:ùëë1ùê∑\mathbf{x}_{d+1:D}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 : italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the rest of ùê±ùê±\mathbf{x}bold_x, sùë†sitalic_s and tùë°titalic_t are scale and translation functions, which are usually implemented as multi-layer perceptrons (MLP), and ‚äôdirect-product\odot‚äô is the element-wise multiplication operator. As noted in Dinh et¬†al. (2016), the affine coupling layer is an invertible function and guarantees fast computation of the determinant of the Jacobian matrix.

First, the inverse function of Equation¬†(2.22) is as follows:

ùê±1:d=ùê≤1:dùê±d+1:D=(ùê≤d+1:D‚àít‚Å¢(ùê≤1:d))‚äôexp‚Å°(‚àís‚Å¢(ùê≤1:d)).subscriptùê±:1ùëësubscriptùê≤:1ùëësubscriptùê±:ùëë1ùê∑direct-productsubscriptùê≤:ùëë1ùê∑ùë°subscriptùê≤:1ùëëùë†subscriptùê≤:1ùëë\begin{split}&\mathbf{x}_{1:d}=\mathbf{y}_{1:d}\\ &\mathbf{x}_{d+1:D}=\left(\mathbf{y}_{d+1:D}-t\left(\mathbf{y}_{1:d}\right)% \right)\odot\exp{\left(-s\left(\mathbf{y}_{1:d}\right)\right)}.\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 : italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 : italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t ( bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ‚äô roman_exp ( - italic_s ( bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) . end_CELL end_ROW (2.23)

Also, the Jacobian matrix of this transformation is

‚àÇùê≤‚àÇùê±‚ä§=[ùïÄd0‚àÇùê≤‚àÇùê±‚ä§diag‚Å°(exp‚Å°[s‚Å¢(ùê±1:d)])],ùê≤superscriptùê±topmatrixsubscriptùïÄùëë0ùê≤superscriptùê±topdiagùë†subscriptùê±:1ùëë\begin{split}\frac{\partial\mathbf{y}}{\partial\mathbf{x}^{\top}}=\begin{% bmatrix}\mathbbm{I}_{d}&0\\ \frac{\partial\mathbf{y}}{\partial\mathbf{x}^{\top}}&\operatorname{diag}\left(% \exp{\left[s(\mathbf{x}_{1:d})\right]}\right)\end{bmatrix},\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG ‚àÇ bold_y end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG ‚àÇ bold_y end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL roman_diag ( roman_exp [ italic_s ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] , end_CELL end_ROW (2.24)

where ùïÄdsubscriptùïÄùëë\mathbbm{I}_{d}blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a d√ódùëëùëëd\times ditalic_d √ó italic_d identity matrix, diag‚Å°(‚àó)diag\operatorname{diag}(*)roman_diag ( ‚àó ) is the diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries correspond to the given matrix and non-diagonal entries are zero.

As a result, the Jacobian matrix shown in Equation¬†(2.24) is a lower-triangular matrix. Therefore, the determinant of the Jacobian matrix can be calculated as follows:

|det(‚àÇy‚àÇx‚ä§)|=‚àèi=1D[‚àÇy‚àÇx‚ä§]i,i=‚àèi=1dexp[s(ùê±1:d)]i,i=exp‚Å°(‚àëi=1d[s‚Å¢(ùê±1:d)]i,i),\begin{split}\left|\det\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial x^{\top}}\right)\right% |&=\prod_{i=1}^{D}\left[\frac{\partial y}{\partial x^{\top}}\right]_{i,i}=% \prod_{i=1}^{d}\exp{\left[s(\mathbf{x}_{1:d})\right]_{i,i}}\\ &=\exp{\left(\sum_{i=1}^{d}\left[s(\mathbf{x}_{1:d})\right]_{i,i}\right)},\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL | roman_det ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_y end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) | end_CELL start_CELL = ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_y end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp [ italic_s ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = roman_exp ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_s ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL end_ROW (2.25)

and

log‚Å°|det(‚àÇy‚àÇx‚ä§)|=‚àëi=1d[s‚Å¢(ùê±1:d)]i,i,ùë¶superscriptùë•topsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëësubscriptdelimited-[]ùë†subscriptùê±:1ùëëùëñùëñ\begin{split}\log\left|\det\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial x^{\top}}\right)% \right|&=\sum_{i=1}^{d}\left[s(\mathbf{x}_{1:d})\right]_{i,i},\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL roman_log | roman_det ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_y end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) | end_CELL start_CELL = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_s ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW (2.26)

where [‚àó]i,isubscriptdelimited-[]ùëñùëñ[*]_{i,i}[ ‚àó ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is iùëñiitalic_i-th diagonal entry of the given matrix.

2.6 Score-Based Generative Models

Score-based generative models are a class of generative models that leverage the concept of ‚Äúscore‚Äù of a probability density function to generate new data samples. The term score is used in a statistical context, referring to the gradient (or intuitively, slope) of the log-likelihood function with respect to the data, ùê±ùê±\mathbf{x}bold_x. Formally, the score is denoted as ‚àáùê±log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)subscript‚àáùê±ùëùùê±\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log p(\mathbf{x})‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ). Intuitively, the score tells us how to change ùê±ùê±\mathbf{x}bold_x to increase the probability of ùê±ùê±\mathbf{x}bold_x under the model‚Äôs current estimate of the probability density function. A higher score indicates a direction in which the data point ùê±ùê±\mathbf{x}bold_x could be adjusted to make it more likely under the model.

In score-based generative models, this concept is used to iteratively refine samples from an initial noise distribution, guiding them towards regions of higher probability under the target distribution (i.e., the distribution of the training data). This is achieved by estimating the score function at various points in the data space and using it to perform gradient ascent on the log-likelihood landscape. Essentially, by following the direction of the score, new data samples can be generated that are likely under the model‚Äôs learned distribution, thus resembling the characteristics of the training data.

The goal of (deep) generative models is to learn the underlying data distribution p‚Å¢(ùê±)ùëùùê±p(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ) given training data samples drawn from true data distribution, {ùê±1,ùê±2,‚ãØ,ùê±N}subscriptùê±1subscriptùê±2‚ãØsubscriptùê±ùëÅ\{\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{N}\}{ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚ãØ , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with ùê±i‚àºp‚Å¢(ùê±),‚àÄi‚àà1,‚ãØ,Nformulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptùê±ùëñùëùùê±for-allùëñ1‚ãØùëÅ\mathbf{x}_{i}\sim p(\mathbf{x}),\forall i\in{1,\cdots,N}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº italic_p ( bold_x ) , ‚àÄ italic_i ‚àà 1 , ‚ãØ , italic_N. The score-based generative models (Song and Ermon, 2019; Song et¬†al., 2020b) focuses on the development of a ‚Äúscore network,‚Äù denoted as sŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±)subscriptùë†ùúÉùê±s_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ), which is essentially a Œ∏ùúÉ\thetaitalic_Œ∏-parameterized neural network designed to approximate the score of the data distribution; that is, sŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±)subscriptùë†ùúÉùê±s_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) aims to be a close estimate of ‚àáùê±log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)subscript‚àáùê±ùëùùê±\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log p(\mathbf{x})‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ). The score network can be trained by minimizing the squared L‚Å¢2ùêø2L2italic_L 2 distance between the ground-truth score and the estimated score by the score network as follows:

ùîºùê±‚àºp‚Å¢(ùê±)‚Å¢‚Äñ‚àáùê±log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)‚àísŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±)‚Äñ22.subscriptùîºsimilar-toùê±ùëùùê±subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript‚àáùê±ùëùùê±subscriptùë†ùúÉùê±22\begin{split}\mathbbm{E}_{\mathbf{x}\sim p(\mathbf{x})}\|\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}% \log p(\mathbf{x})-s_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}_{2}.\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ‚àº italic_p ( bold_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ) - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (2.27)

A significant challenge with this approach is that it involves direct access to ‚àáùê±log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)subscript‚àáùê±ùëùùê±\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log p(\mathbf{x})‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ), which is not practically feasible. To address this issue, a substantial body of research has been dedicated to developing alternative methodologies, collectively known as ‚Äúscore matching‚Äù (Hyv√§rinen and Dayan, 2005; Vincent, 2011; Song et¬†al., 2020a) that minimizes Equation¬†(2.27) without having to have access to the ground-truth data score.

One of the main concerns in score-based generative models is figuring out how the score network can be efficiently and accurately trained. Song and Ermon (2019) identified several challenges in training the score network. One of the main challenges is that since most training data is located in a small subspace of the high dimensional data space, training the score network in low data density regions can be challenging.

Therefore, Song and Ermon (2019) proposed to perturb the data space using a scheduled Gaussian noise and learn the score function using the perturbed data following Vincent (2011). This approach is also called ‚Äúdenoising score matching,‚Äù and as shown in Vincent (2011), if the perturbation is small enough, learning the score function of a perturbed data distribution (qœÉ‚Å¢(ùê±~|ùê±)subscriptùëûùúéconditional~ùê±ùê±q_{\sigma}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{x}}|\mathbf{x}\right)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG | bold_x )) is almost surely equivalent to learning the actual score function of p‚Å¢(ùê±)ùëùùê±p(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ), i.e., ‚àáùê±log‚Å°qœÉ‚Å¢(ùê±~|ùê±)‚âà‚àáùê±subscript‚àáùê±subscriptùëûùúéconditional~ùê±ùê±subscript‚àáùê±\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log q_{\sigma}(\tilde{\mathbf{x}}|\mathbf{x})\approx\nabla% _{\mathbf{x}}‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG | bold_x ) ‚âà ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, the updated learning objective is as follows:

ùîºùê±‚àºp‚Å¢(ùê±)‚Å¢[ùîºùê±~‚àºqœÉ‚Å¢(ùê±~|ùê±)‚Å¢‚à•‚àáùê±log‚Å°qœÉ‚Å¢(ùê±~|ùê±)‚àísŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±~)‚à•22]=ùîºùê±‚àºp‚Å¢(ùê±)‚Å¢[ùîºùê±~‚àºùí©‚Å¢(ùê±,œÉ2‚Å¢ùïÄ)‚Å¢‚à•ùê±~‚àíùê±œÉ2‚àísŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±~)‚à•22],subscriptùîºsimilar-toùê±ùëùùê±delimited-[]subscriptùîºsimilar-to~ùê±subscriptùëûùúéconditional~ùê±ùê±subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript‚àáùê±subscriptùëûùúéconditional~ùê±ùê±subscriptùë†ùúÉ~ùê±22subscriptùîºsimilar-toùê±ùëùùê±delimited-[]subscriptùîºsimilar-to~ùê±ùí©ùê±superscriptùúé2ùïÄsubscriptsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•~ùê±ùê±superscriptùúé2subscriptùë†ùúÉ~ùê±22\begin{split}&\mathbbm{E}_{\mathbf{x}\sim p(\mathbf{x})}\left[\mathbbm{E}_{% \tilde{\mathbf{x}}\sim q_{\sigma}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{x}}|\mathbf{x}\right)}% \left\lVert\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log q_{\sigma}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{x}}|\mathbf{% x}\right)-s_{\theta}(\tilde{\mathbf{x}})\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]\\ =&\mathbbm{E}_{\mathbf{x}\sim p(\mathbf{x})}\left[\mathbbm{E}_{\tilde{\mathbf{% x}}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{x},\sigma^{2}\mathbbm{I}\right)}\left\lVert% \frac{\tilde{\mathbf{x}}-\mathbf{x}}{\sigma^{2}}-s_{\theta}(\tilde{\mathbf{x}}% )\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right],\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ‚àº italic_p ( bold_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ‚àº italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG | bold_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG | bold_x ) - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL = end_CELL start_CELL blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ‚àº italic_p ( bold_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ‚àº caligraphic_N ( bold_x , italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG - bold_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , end_CELL end_ROW (2.28)

where, ùê±~~ùê±\tilde{\mathbf{x}}over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG is the perturbed data with Gaussian distribution with standard deviation œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ. Song and Ermon (2019) further proposed to use a variance scheduling for data perturbation. Formally, we can define a set of standard deviation of data perturbation, {œÉt}t=1Lsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùë°ùêøùë°1\{\sigma_{t}\}^{L}_{t=1}{ italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, that satisfies œÉ1œÉ2=‚ãØ=œÉL‚àí1œÉL>1subscriptùúé1subscriptùúé2‚ãØsubscriptùúéùêø1subscriptùúéùêø1\frac{\sigma_{1}}{\sigma_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{\sigma_{L-1}}{\sigma_{L}}>1divide start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = ‚ãØ = divide start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG > 1. Specifically, we start from a large enough data perturbation that can cover (or generate data in) the low data density regions in the data space, and then we gradually decrease the perturbation so that the learned score function can match with the actual score function. Intuitively, we can interpret the large perturbation as learning the general trend or landscape of the score function. In contrast, we can interpret the small perturbation as learning the details of the actual score function.

Then, the score network is trained given the current noise level (œÉtsubscriptùúéùë°\sigma_{t}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and this is called the ‚ÄúNoise Conditional Score Network.‚Äù For a given œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ, the updated learning objective is:

ùîºùê±‚àºp‚Å¢(ùê±)‚Å¢[ùîºùê±~‚àºùí©‚Å¢(ùê±,œÉ2‚Å¢ùïÄ)‚Å¢‚à•ùê±~‚àíùê±œÉ2‚àísŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±~,œÉ)‚à•22].subscriptùîºsimilar-toùê±ùëùùê±delimited-[]subscriptùîºsimilar-to~ùê±ùí©ùê±superscriptùúé2ùïÄsubscriptsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•~ùê±ùê±superscriptùúé2subscriptùë†ùúÉ~ùê±ùúé22\begin{split}\mathbbm{E}_{\mathbf{x}\sim p(\mathbf{x})}\left[\mathbbm{E}_{% \tilde{\mathbf{x}}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{x},\sigma^{2}\mathbbm{I}\right)% }\left\lVert\frac{\tilde{\mathbf{x}}-\mathbf{x}}{\sigma^{2}}-s_{\theta}(\tilde% {\mathbf{x}},\sigma)\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right].\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ‚àº italic_p ( bold_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ‚àº caligraphic_N ( bold_x , italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG - bold_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , italic_œÉ ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] . end_CELL end_ROW (2.29)

Once the score network is trained, data generation can be accomplished through an iterative method known as Langevin dynamics, or Langevin Monte Carlo (Parisi, 1981; Grenander and Miller, 1994). Langevin dynamics is originally formulated to describe the behavior of molecular systems, such as Brownian motion. A more detailed derivation of equations for Langevin dynamics in the generative model setting is presented in Appendix¬†B. Given a fixed step size œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0italic_œµ > 0, and an initial random noise ùê±ùê±\mathbf{x}bold_x, the following iterative procedure can be used:

ùê±i+1‚Üêùê±i+‚àáxlog‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)‚ãÖœµ+2‚Å¢œµ‚ãÖùê≥i,‚Üêsubscriptùê±ùëñ1subscriptùê±ùëñ‚ãÖsubscript‚àáùë•ùëùùê±italic-œµ‚ãÖ2italic-œµsubscriptùê≥ùëñ\mathbf{x}_{i+1}\leftarrow\mathbf{x}_{i}+\nabla_{x}\log p(\mathbf{x})\cdot% \epsilon+\sqrt{2\epsilon}\cdot\mathbf{z}_{i},bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üê bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ) ‚ãÖ italic_œµ + square-root start_ARG 2 italic_œµ end_ARG ‚ãÖ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (2.30)

where ùê≥i‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0,I)similar-tosubscriptùê≥ùëñùí©0ùêº\mathbf{z}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I)bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I ). Since the values from the trained score network should match the true score, we can use the following iterative procedure to draw samples from the distribution of interest:

ùê±i+1‚Üêùê±i+sŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±i)‚ãÖœµ+2‚Å¢œµ‚ãÖùê≥i.‚Üêsubscriptùê±ùëñ1subscriptùê±ùëñ‚ãÖsubscriptùë†ùúÉsubscriptùê±ùëñitalic-œµ‚ãÖ2italic-œµsubscriptùê≥ùëñ\mathbf{x}_{i+1}\leftarrow\mathbf{x}_{i}+s_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}_{i})\cdot% \epsilon+\sqrt{2\epsilon}\cdot\mathbf{z}_{i}.bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üê bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ italic_œµ + square-root start_ARG 2 italic_œµ end_ARG ‚ãÖ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (2.31)

2.7 Diffusion Models

Diffusion models are a class of DGMs that have shown a remarkable ability to generate high-quality samples across various domains. The core concept behind diffusion models is inspired by the physical process of ‚Äúdiffusion,‚Äù where particles move from areas of higher concentration to lower concentration until they reach an equilibrium. Diffusion models work by gradually adding noise to data until it becomes indistinguishable random noise (known as a forward diffusion process, or diffusion process), and then learning the reverse of this process of denoising the data (known as a reverse diffusion process, or generation process).

Figure¬†5 shows the general framework of the diffusion model. We start from ùê±0subscriptùê±0\mathbf{x}_{0}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which is the real data. At each diffusion step, we add a small noise. After a sufficiently large number of steps (here we denote it as kùëòkitalic_k), the data is nearly complete noise as shown in ùê±k=ùê≥subscriptùê±ùëòùê≥\mathbf{x}_{k}=\mathbf{z}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_z. The forward process of adding noise is given, and the main ‚Äòlearning‚Äô part of the diffusion model is to learn the reverse process which transforms the complete noise ùê≥ùê≥\mathbf{z}bold_z to the data ùê±0subscriptùê±0\mathbf{x}_{0}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is similar to VAE, GAN, and Normalizing Flows that we start from a complete noise (or well-known distribution such as Gaussian distribution or uniform distribution) and we learn to transform the noise into the data distribution p‚Å¢(ùê±)ùëùùê±p(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ). The main difference is the idea inspired by the physical ‚Äúdiffusion‚Äù process and denoising process which recovers the data from a complete noise.

Ho et¬†al. (2020) presents the Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model, or DDPM, which extends the diffusion model framework by incorporating a denoising autoencoder-like architecture. This architecture allows for more efficient learning of the reverse diffusion process, enabling the model to generate high-fidelity samples from complex data distributions.

The forward diffusion process is designed to corrupt the original data ùê±0subscriptùê±0\mathbf{x}_{0}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over a series of time steps t=1,2,‚Ä¶,Tùë°12‚Ä¶ùëát=1,2,\ldots,Titalic_t = 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_T. At each step tùë°titalic_t, Gaussian noise is added to the data, which is mathematically described by the conditional distribution q‚Å¢(ùê±t|ùê±t‚àí1)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1q(\mathbf{x}_{t}|\mathbf{x}_{t-1})italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). This distribution specifies how the data at step tùë°titalic_t is generated from the data at the previous step t‚àí1ùë°1t-1italic_t - 1.

Formally, the forward process is defined as:

q‚Å¢(ùê±t|ùê±t‚àí1)=ùí©‚Å¢(ùê±t;1‚àíŒ≤t‚Å¢ùê±t‚àí1,Œ≤t‚Å¢ùïÄ),ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1ùí©subscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùõΩùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùõΩùë°ùïÄq(\mathbf{x}_{t}|\mathbf{x}_{t-1})=\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_{t};\sqrt{1-\beta_{t% }}\mathbf{x}_{t-1},\beta_{t}\mathbbm{I}),italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_N ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; square-root start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I ) , (2.32)

where q‚Å¢(ùê±t|ùê±t‚àí1)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1q(\mathbf{x}_{t}|\mathbf{x}_{t-1})italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) follows the conditional Gaussian distribution with mean 1‚àíŒ≤t‚Å¢ùê±t‚àí11subscriptùõΩùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1\sqrt{1-\beta_{t}}\mathbf{x}_{t-1}square-root start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and covariance Œ≤t‚Å¢ùïÄsubscriptùõΩùë°ùïÄ\beta_{t}\mathbbm{I}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I, tùë°titalic_t is the diffusion timestep, and Œ≤tsubscriptùõΩùë°\beta_{t}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a time-dependent coefficient that controls the amount of data retained from the previous step where 0<Œ≤t‚â™10subscriptùõΩùë°much-less-than10<\beta_{t}\ll 10 < italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â™ 1. The choice of 1‚àíŒ≤t1subscriptùõΩùë°\sqrt{1-\beta_{t}}square-root start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG and Œ≤tsubscriptùõΩùë°\beta_{t}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ensures that the variance of each diffusion step is maintained at 1. This is important because it stabilizes the diffusion process, preventing the variance from either exploding or vanishing over time.

Based on the reparameterization trick, the transition from ùê±t‚àí1subscriptùê±ùë°1\mathbf{x}_{t-1}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to ùê±tsubscriptùê±ùë°\mathbf{x}_{t}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be also expressed as:

ùê±t=1‚àíŒ≤t‚Å¢ùê±t‚àí1+Œ≤t‚Å¢œµt,subscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùõΩùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùõΩùë°subscriptbold-italic-œµùë°\mathbf{x}_{t}=\sqrt{1-\beta_{t}}\mathbf{x}_{t-1}+\beta_{t}\boldsymbol{% \epsilon}_{t},bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (2.33)

where œµt‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0,I)similar-tosubscriptbold-italic-œµùë°ùí©0ùêº\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{t}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I)bold_italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I ) is Gaussian noise with mean 0 and identity covariance matrix.

From Equation¬†(2.32), we can derive the equation for q‚Å¢(ùê±0:T)ùëûsubscriptùê±:0ùëáq(\mathbf{x}_{0:T})italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 : italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) representing the diffusion trajectory from the original data ùê±0subscriptùê±0\mathbf{x}_{0}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the complete noise ùê±T=zsubscriptùê±ùëáùëß\mathbf{x}_{T}=zbold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z based on properties of Markov chain and chain rules as follows:

q‚Å¢(ùê±0:T)=q‚Å¢(ùê±0)‚Å¢‚àèt=1Tq‚Å¢(ùê±t|ùê±t‚àí1),or,q‚Å¢(ùê±1:T|ùê±0)=‚àèt=1Tq‚Å¢(ùê±t|ùê±t‚àí1).formulae-sequenceùëûsubscriptùê±:0ùëáùëûsubscriptùê±0superscriptsubscriptproductùë°1ùëáùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1or,ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±:1ùëásubscriptùê±0superscriptsubscriptproductùë°1ùëáùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1\begin{split}&q\left(\mathbf{x}_{0:T})=q(\mathbf{x}_{0}\right)\prod_{t=1}^{T}q% \left(\mathbf{x}_{t}|\mathbf{x}_{t-1}\right),\\ &\text{or,}\\ &q\left(\mathbf{x}_{1:T}|\mathbf{x}_{0}\right)=\prod_{t=1}^{T}q\left(\mathbf{x% }_{t}|\mathbf{x}_{t-1}\right).\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 : italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL or, end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . end_CELL end_ROW (2.34)

The reverse diffusion process (the denoising process) represents the generative distribution parameterized with Œ∏ùúÉ\thetaitalic_Œ∏. The joint distribution pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±0:T)subscriptùëùùúÉsubscriptùê±:0ùëáp_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{0:T}\right)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 : italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is defined as a Markov chain with Gaussian transition distributions, pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t)subscriptùëùùúÉconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t}\right)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) starting at p‚Å¢(ùê±T)=ùí©‚Å¢(ùê±T;ùüé,ùïÄ)ùëùsubscriptùê±ùëáùí©subscriptùê±ùëá0ùïÄp\left(\mathbf{x}_{T}\right)=\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_{T};\mathbf{0},\mathbbm{I})italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_N ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_0 , blackboard_I ) as follows:

pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±0:T)=p‚Å¢(ùê±T)‚Å¢‚àèt=1TpŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t),subscriptùëùùúÉsubscriptùê±:0ùëáùëùsubscriptùê±ùëásuperscriptsubscriptproductùë°1ùëásubscriptùëùùúÉconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{0:T}\right)=p\left(\mathbf{x}_{T}\right)\prod_{t=1% }^{T}p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t}\right),italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 : italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (2.35)

where

pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t)=ùí©‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1;ùùÅŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±t,t),ùö∫Œ∏‚Å¢(ùê±t,t)).subscriptùëùùúÉconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°ùí©subscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùùÅùúÉsubscriptùê±ùë°ùë°subscriptùö∫ùúÉsubscriptùê±ùë°ùë°p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t}\right)=\mathcal{N}\left(% \mathbf{x}_{t-1};\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}_{t},t),\mathbf{\Sigma}_{% \theta}(\mathbf{x}_{t},t)\right).italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_N ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) ) . (2.36)

Similar to VAE and Normalizing Flows (models using explicit densities for training), the training objective is to maximize the likelihood or minimize the negative log-likelihood

Œ∏‚àó=arg‚Å°minŒ∏‚Å°ùîº‚Å¢[‚àílog‚Å°pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±0)].superscriptùúÉsubscriptùúÉùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëùùúÉsubscriptùê±0\theta^{*}=\arg\min_{\theta}\mathbbm{E}\left[-\log p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_% {0}\right)\right].italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ - roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] . (2.37)

Instead of directly training the model with negative log-likelihood, we can consider qùëûqitalic_q as the approximate posterior and use the variational bound on negative log-likelihood to train the model. A detailed derivation is presented in Appendix¬†A and Ho et¬†al. (2020). As a result, we can find an upper bound of the optimization

ùîº‚Å¢[‚àílog‚Å°pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±0)]‚â§ùîº‚Å¢[DK‚Å¢L(q(ùê±T|ùê±0)||p(ùê±T))‚èüLT+‚àët=2TDK‚Å¢L(q(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t,ùê±0)||pŒ∏(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t))‚èüLt‚àí1‚Å¢‚àílog‚Å°pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±0|ùê±1)‚èüL0].\begin{split}\mathbbm{E}\left[-\log p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{0}\right)% \right]\leq\mathbbm{E}\left[\underbrace{D_{KL}\left(q\left(\mathbf{x}_{T}|% \mathbf{x}_{0}\right)||p\left(\mathbf{x}_{T}\right)\right)}_{L_{T}}+\sum_{t=2}% ^{T}\underbrace{D_{KL}\left(q\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t},\mathbf{x}_% {0}\right)||p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t}\right)\right)}_{L_% {t-1}}\underbrace{-\log p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{0}|\mathbf{x}_{1}\right)}_% {L_{0}}\right].\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E [ - roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ‚â§ blackboard_E [ under‚èü start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | | italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT under‚èü start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under‚èü start_ARG - roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] . end_CELL end_ROW (2.38)

Therefore, the overall loss function of minimizing the negative log-likelihood in Equation¬†(2.37) is decomposed into several losses, LTsubscriptùêøùëáL_{T}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Lt‚àí1subscriptùêøùë°1L_{t-1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and L0subscriptùêø0L_{0}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here, LTsubscriptùêøùëáL_{T}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is constant since both q‚Å¢(ùê±T|ùê±0)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùëásubscriptùê±0q\left(\mathbf{x}_{T}|\mathbf{x}_{0}\right)italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and p‚Å¢(ùê±T)ùëùsubscriptùê±ùëáp\left(\mathbf{x}_{T}\right)italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are fixed, and therefore, we can ignore this term. Also, in Ho and Ermon (2016), L0subscriptùêø0L_{0}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is explicitly defined by using the characteristics of the image generation problem, and as a result, L0subscriptùêø0L_{0}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be interpreted as a reconstruction loss of a problem-specific decoder. As a result, the actual learning process of the diffusion model is related to Lt‚àí1subscriptùêøùë°1L_{t-1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Lt‚àí1subscriptùêøùë°1L_{t-1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measures the KL-divergence of q‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t,ùê±0)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±0q\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t},\mathbf{x}_{0}\right)italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) from pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t)subscriptùëùùúÉconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t}\right)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The diffusion process, qùëûqitalic_q, represents the process of adding small noise to the data; i.e., given a less noisy data ùê±t‚àí1subscriptùê±ùë°1\mathbf{x}_{t-1}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the distribution of a more noisy data ùê±tsubscriptùê±ùë°\mathbf{x}_{t}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The first term, q‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t,ùê±0)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±0q\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t},\mathbf{x}_{0}\right)italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), represents the true denoising process which is derived from the definition of qùëûqitalic_q given the true data without noise, ùê±0subscriptùê±0\mathbf{x}_{0}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. What the diffusion models try to learn is the denoising process pŒ∏‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t)subscriptùëùùúÉconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°p_{\theta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t}\right)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ); i.e., given a more noisy data ùê±tsubscriptùê±ùë°\mathbf{x}_{t}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the distribution of a less noisy data ùê±t‚àí1subscriptùê±ùë°1\mathbf{x}_{t-1}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As a result, Lt‚àí1subscriptùêøùë°1L_{t-1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT captures the distributional difference between the true denoising process (given the true data) and the approximated denoising process (without the true data).

Since the diffusion process follows Gaussian distribution, the true reverse process, q‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t,ùê±0)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±0q\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t},\mathbf{x}_{0}\right)italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), can be assumed to follow a Gaussian distribution if TùëáTitalic_T is sufficiently large, or T‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëáT\rightarrow\inftyitalic_T ‚Üí ‚àû. Let q‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1|ùê±t,ùê±0)=ùí©‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1;ùùÅ~t‚Å¢(ùê±t,ùê±0),Œ≤~t‚Å¢ùïÄ)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±0ùí©subscriptùê±ùë°1subscript~ùùÅùë°subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±0subscript~ùõΩùë°ùïÄq\left(\mathbf{x}_{t-1}|\mathbf{x}_{t},\mathbf{x}_{0}\right)=\mathcal{N}(% \mathbf{x}_{t-1};\tilde{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t},\mathbf{x}_{0}),% \tilde{\beta}_{t}\mathbbm{I})italic_q ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_N ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I ). To derive explicit form of ùùÅ~t‚Å¢(ùê±t,ùê±0)subscript~ùùÅùë°subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±0\tilde{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t},\mathbf{x}_{0})over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Œ≤~tsubscript~ùõΩùë°\tilde{\beta}_{t}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, first, we should derive a closed-form equation for sampling ùê±tsubscriptùê±ùë°\mathbf{x}_{t}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at an arbitrary timestep tùë°titalic_t from Equation¬†(2.32) as follows:

Then, Ho et¬†al. (2020) found that using Ls‚Å¢i‚Å¢m‚Å¢p‚Å¢l‚Å¢esubscriptùêøùë†ùëñùëöùëùùëôùëíL_{simple}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_i italic_m italic_p italic_l italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT results in better training in empirical testing.

Ls‚Å¢i‚Å¢m‚Å¢p‚Å¢l‚Å¢e=ùîºt,ùê±0,œµ‚Å¢[‚à•œµ‚àíœµŒ∏‚Å¢(Œ±¬Øt‚Å¢ùê±0+1‚àíŒ±¬Øt‚Å¢œµ,t)‚à•22].subscriptùêøùë†ùëñùëöùëùùëôùëísubscriptùîºùë°subscriptùê±0bold-italic-œµdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•bold-italic-œµsubscriptbold-italic-œµùúÉsubscript¬Øùõºùë°subscriptùê±01subscript¬Øùõºùë°bold-italic-œµùë°22L_{simple}=\mathbbm{E}_{t,\mathbf{x}_{0},\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}\left[\left% \lVert\boldsymbol{\epsilon}-\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{\theta}\left(\sqrt{\bar{% \alpha}}_{t}\mathbf{x}_{0}+\sqrt{1-\bar{\alpha}_{t}}\boldsymbol{\epsilon},t% \right)\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\right].italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_i italic_m italic_p italic_l italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ‚à• bold_italic_œµ - bold_italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( square-root start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG 1 - over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_œµ , italic_t ) ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] . (2.39)

2.8 Discussion

Different classes of Deep Generative Models (DGMs) use various approaches to model data distributions. Since all models have their imperfections, it‚Äôs crucial to understand the commonly known pros and cons of each class. Typically, we expect three key things from DGMs: 1) High-Quality Sample Generation ‚Äî The ability to produce samples that are indistinguishable from real data; 2) Mode Coverage and Sample Diversity ‚Äî The capacity to capture all the variations in the data, including minority modes, ensuring that the generated samples are diverse and representative of the entire data distribution; and 3) Fast and Computationally Efficient Sampling‚Äî The ability to generate samples quickly without requiring extensive computational resources.

However, most DGMs cannot yet simultaneously satisfy these three key requirements, a challenge often referred to as the Generative Learning Trilemma (Xiao et¬†al., 2021). This trilemma highlights the inherent trade-offs between high-quality sample generation, mode coverage and diversity, and fast, computationally efficient sampling. For example, Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) have the advantage of generating high-quality samples rapidly. As discussed in Section¬†2.4, GANs are renowned for producing realistic samples through a single forward pass of the generator network, making them computationally efficient at inference time. However, common shortcomings of GANs include mode collapse, where the model fails to capture the full diversity of the data distribution, generating samples from only some modes but not all. On the other hand, Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) and Normalizing Flows usually perform well in terms of mode coverage and fast computation time. VAEs promote diverse and representative sampling by modeling the entire data distribution, and they allow for quick sample generation by direct decoding from latent variables. Normalizing Flows also enables efficient sampling and exact density estimation. However, the quality of the samples generated by VAEs and Normalizing Flows may not be as high as those produced by other models. Diffusion Models present another approach, capable of covering diverse modes and generating high-quality samples. Recent advances have enabled diffusion models to produce samples that rival or even surpass GANs in terms of quality and diversity. However, diffusion models typically consist of a large number of denoising steps (often ranging from 500 to 1000), which require substantial computation to generate a single sample. This makes the sampling process slow and computationally expensive compared to other models.

As a result, understanding these trade-offs of using each class of DGM is essential when applying DGMs in practice. Since no current model perfectly satisfies all three key requirements, researchers should choose the model class that best aligns with the specific needs of their application, whether that be sample quality, diversity, or computational efficiency. Additionally, some previous research has explored combining different modeling approaches from several DGMs, such as Xiao et¬†al. (2021) which combined Diffusion models with GAN, Grover et¬†al. (2018) which combined Normalizing Flows with GAN, and Zhang and Chen (2021) which combined Normalizing Flows with Diffusion model. These examples demonstrate that by integrating different DGMs, researchers can also address the limitations imposed by using a single DGM.

Deep Generative Models in Different Areas of Transportation Research

DGMs have become important in current research for their ability to model complex data distributions and generate data samples that closely mimic real-world observations. Particularly, in transportation research, DGMs offer tools to simulate, predict, and optimize transportation systems effectively (Huynh and Phung, 2021; Lin et¬†al., 2023a; Yan and Li, 2023). Therefore, in this section, we provide a systematic review of the applications of DGMs in transportation research.

This review focuses on three main areas where DGMs have significantly impacted transportation research: data generation, estimation and prediction, and unsupervised representation learning. By examining their applications in these areas, we gain a clear understanding of how DGMs impacted and will impact transportation research. An overview of this section is shown in Figure¬†6.

  1. 1.

    DGM for data generation: The core functionality of DGMs lies in their ability to generate realistic synthetic data that closely replicate real-world conditions. This capability is particularly valuable in transportation research, where collecting large, high-quality datasets can be challenging and costly. Through the generation of diverse traffic scenarios, DGMs enable researchers to investigate situations that are difficult to capture through traditional data collection methods.

  2. 2.

    DGM for estimation and prediction: Beyond generating data, DGMs are also highly effective for estimation and prediction tasks. DGMs learn the underlying distribution of the given (training) data, and as a result, they can model the inherent uncertainties and variations in traffic data. This capability allows DGMs to provide probabilistic estimations and forecasts of traffic states. The probabilistic approach enhances the accuracy, robustness, and reliability of predictions, which support better decision-making in transportation planning and operation.

  3. 3.

    DGM for unsupervised representation learning: Most DGMs are designed to learn the transformation function from a sample from a simple distribution (also known as a base distribution) to a target distribution. The ‚Äònoisy‚Äô data sample from the base distribution can be considered as a latent representation of the synthetic data sample. These latent representations can be used for various analyses, such as classifying transportation modes, detecting traffic anomalies, or understanding driving behaviors. This ability to derive insights without requiring labeled data makes DGMs powerful tools in unsupervised learning scenarios.

3.1 DGM for Data Generation

The rapid urbanization of society requires effective traffic management systems to reduce congestion, improve urban planning, and enhance transportation network efficiency (Xu et¬†al., 2015). These systems are fundamentally built on large volumes of high-quality traffic data. Sufficient data volume is essential for accurate analyses and modeling of complex traffic behaviors and patterns, while data quality ensures precise and reliable insights and applications. Despite advancements in technology that have improved data collection capabilities in transportation, traffic sensors often face issues of sparsity and unreliability, making it challenging to obtain adequate, high-quality data in real-world scenarios (Chen et¬†al., 2003; Ni and Leonard, 2005). DGMs address these challenges by both increasing the volume and improving the quality of traffic datasets. They can generate synthetic data to supplement existing datasets, effectively expanding their size. Additionally, DGMs replicate real-world conditions with high fidelity, which enhances the dataset‚Äôs qualitative aspects. These capabilities are particularly valuable for transportation research, where traditional data collection methods may be costly, time-consuming, and impractical, especially for capturing rare or non-reproducible scenarios. For example, synthetic data generated by DGMs can simulate a range of traffic conditions, from typical daily commutes to rare events like accidents or extreme weather. Consequently, the synthetic data from DGMs is crucial for developing robust traffic models and systems that can handle a wide range of scenarios. In the following sections, we will explore data generation through DGMs in three key areas: scenario and synthetic data generation, trajectory generation, and missing data imputation.

3.1.1¬†¬†¬†Scenario and Synthetic Data Generation

Scenario and synthetic data generation involve using DGMs to produce a wide range of synthetic data. This process includes creating diverse driving scenarios to test and evaluate autonomous vehicles, synthesizing demographic and travel behavior data to represent different populations in studies, and generating synthetic traffic data for training other machine learning models for traffic operation and management. Additionally, DGMs can generate rare or unexpected traffic situations to improve anomaly detection and response strategies. These capabilities allow researchers to simulate various conditions and events which can help enhance the robustness and accuracy of analysis. This section highlights how the DGMs enable comprehensive testing, analysis, and improvement of transportation networks through effective scenario and synthetic data generation.

3.1.1.1¬†¬†¬†Driving Scenario Generation

Many studies in this section have focused on driving scenario generation, which involves creating diverse and realistic driving situations to test and evaluate autonomous vehicles and traffic management systems (Ghosh et¬†al., 2016; Yun et¬†al., 2019; Singh et¬†al., 2023; Ye et¬†al., 2022; Jin et¬†al., 2023; Dong et¬†al., 2023; Xu et¬†al., 2023b; Huang et¬†al., 2024; Li et¬†al., 2024d). Most of these studies utilize additional information as conditions for their generative models, such as car-following theory, safety critics, or physical restrictions, to generate more realistic and high-performing models. For example, Chen et¬†al. (2022a) developed a two-step hybrid driving model that combines model-based controllers with Generative Adversarial Imitation Learning (GAIL) for traffic simulation. The model generates high-level driver traits used as parameters for low-level model-based controllers to simulate human-like driving in multi-agent traffic scenarios. Zhong et¬†al. (2023) presented a framework using a conditional diffusion model to generate realistic and controllable traffic simulations. The key benefit of the model is that it allows users to specify trajectory properties, such as reaching a goal or following speed limits while ensuring that the generated trajectories are physically feasible and realistic through the guidance of signal temporal logic rules. Similarly, Sun et¬†al. (2023) introduced a data-driven method DriverSceneGen for generating diverse and realistic driving scenarios to address data limitations. DriverSceneGen employed a diffusion model to create initial driving scenes in a rasterized Bird-Eye-View (BEV) format and used a simulation network to predict multiple future scenarios based on the initial setup. Furthermore, Xu et¬†al. (2023a) developed DiffScene, a diffusion-based framework designed to generate safety-critical driving scenarios for evaluating and enhancing autonomous vehicle safety. DiffScene used a diffusion model to approximate the distribution of low-density areas in traffic data, creating realistic safety-critical situations. These scenarios were further optimized using guided adversarial objectives to maintain both realism and safety-criticality. Additionally, Zhang et¬†al. (2020a) employed the conditional GAIL (cGAIL) framework to study taxi drivers‚Äô decision-making strategies. The method transferred knowledge across different drivers and locations to improve policy accuracy, improving taxi drivers‚Äô income and service quality. These studies have demonstrated the capability of using DGMs in driving scenario generation by providing more diverse and realistic scenarios for traffic management and Autonomous Vehicle development.

3.1.1.2¬†¬†¬†Population Synthesis

Population synthesis is a critical component of transportation research that involves generating synthetic demographic and travel behavior data to accurately represent populations. This synthetic data is essential for effectively modeling and analyzing transportation systems. Many studies have utilized VAEs or GAN-based models to solve the problems (Borysov et¬†al., 2018; Badu-Marfo et¬†al., 2020; Mensah et¬†al., 2022; Johnsen et¬†al., 2022; Badu-Marfo et¬†al., 2022). For instance, Borysov et¬†al. (2019) presented a VAE-based approach for population synthesis to address common challenges, such as scalability and the issue of sampling zeros in previous methods. The proposed method fits the full joint distribution of high-dimensional data, enabling the generation of more comprehensive synthetic datasets. Validation with a large-scale Danish trip diary dataset demonstrated the method‚Äôs effectiveness in enhancing the realism and diversity of synthetic populations. Kim and Bansal (2023) also tackled the challenges of structural zeros and the generation of feasible, diverse synthetic populations. They employed customized loss functions for the VAE and Wasserstein GAN (WGANs) and validated their approach using a large household travel survey dataset from South Korea. Similarly, Garrido et¬†al. (2020) proposed a VAE and WGAN-based method to predict rare feature combinations in population synthesis. These models generate synthetic populations that include rare and diverse feature combinations throughout capturing the joint distribution of high-dimensional attributes. Validation with the Danish National Travel Survey data demonstrated notable improvements in generating realistic and varied synthetic populations.These studies collectively highlight the versatility and robustness of DGMs in population synthesis. They underscore the importance of DGMs in creating realistic and diverse synthetic data, which is crucial for accurate transportation modeling and analysis.

3.1.1.3¬†¬†¬†Synthetic Data and Model Training

The DGM can also be used to generate various types of synthetic traffic data for traffic modeling and training purposes. These synthetic datasets enable researchers to simulate traffic scenarios and train models without relying solely on real-world data, which can be expensive and difficult to collect. In related research, instead of using basic models, most researchers combine various deep learning architectures or incorporate additional information to further improve performance (Chen et¬†al., 2019; Ozturk et¬†al., 2020; Wu et¬†al., 2020; Chen et¬†al., 2021c; Zhou et¬†al., 2023; Rong et¬†al., 2023b; Kumar et¬†al., 2023; Devadhas¬†Sujakumari and Dassan, 2023). For traffic data generation, Li et¬†al. (2022a) proposed the Attentive Dual-Head Spatial-Temporal GAN (ADST-GAN) to generate crowd flows. The model integrates attentive temporal and spatial mechanisms by combining ConvLSTM, self-attention, and a dual-head discriminator within the GAN framework. These components capture complex spatial-temporal dependencies in crowd flow data and mitigate overfitting, ensuring that the synthetic data generated closely mimics real-world traffic patterns. To address the complexity of modeling Origin-Destination (OD) networks, Rong et¬†al. (2023a) introduced a large-scale OD generation method using a graph-denoising diffusion model. This approach simplifies the generation process by decomposing it into two stages: first, generating the network topology, and second, generating the edge weights. By tackling these stages separately, the model accurately generates realistic OD data, making the analysis of large-scale OD networks more manageable. For model training, Dewi et¬†al. (2022) applied a Deep Convolutional GAN (DCGAN) to generate synthetic traffic sign images. This approach captures the distribution of real traffic sign images and produces new samples to augment the original dataset. The researcher further combined these synthetic images with real ones to improve the performance of deep recognition models, such as CNN and ResNet 50. Additionally, Zhu et¬†al. (2022) employed the Spatio-Temporal Dependencies GAN (STDGAN) to generate high-quality synthetic traffic volume data for prediction tasks. Specifically, STDGAN captures implicit variation patterns in traffic volume based on information from traffic speed and occupancy data. Experiment results indicate that enriching the training dataset with the synthetic volume data led to more robust and accurate performance in prediction models. These examples demonstrate the ability of DGMs to generate various traffic data that support traffic management and enhance model training, offering valuable resources for transportation research and applications.

3.1.1.4¬†¬†¬†Anomaly Data Generation

Anomaly data generation is crucial for creating rare or unexpected traffic situations, which are essential for testing and evaluating systems under extreme conditions. Generating such data helps develop robust models that can handle these rare events effectively. In this research field, GAN-based models are widely adopted due to their flexible and high performance in generating synthetic data for anomaly situations (Islam et¬†al., 2021; Zarei and Hellinga, 2021; Li et¬†al., 2024a; Chen et¬†al., 2024). For instance, Cai et¬†al. (2020) utilized a DCGAN to generate synthetic crash data from learning the distribution of crash-related traffic data. The synthetic data was then combined with real data to create a balanced dataset, which was used to train various crash prediction algorithms, including Logistic Regression, SVM, ANN, and CNN. Similarly, Chen et¬†al. (2022d) employed two GAN variants‚ÄîConditional GAN (CGAN) and Gaussian Discriminant Analysis GAN (GDAGAN)‚Äîto tackle the challenge of imbalanced traffic collision datasets. These generative models generated additional samples for underrepresented classes, thereby balancing the dataset and enhancing the performance of classifiers trained on them. Huo et¬†al. (2021) introduced the Text-to-Traffic GAN (T2GAN), which generates realistic traffic situations by integrating traffic data with semantic information from social media. In the proposed model, CGAN was used to generate traffic scenarios based on text inputs from social media, which enables the creation of varied and contextually rich traffic situations. To tackle data imbalance in traffic crash severity modeling, Chen et¬†al. (2024) developed a method based on Conditional Tabular GAN (CTGAN) combined with Random Under-sampling (CTGAN-RU). This approach generated synthetic crash data while accounting for both continuous and discrete characteristics of the imbalanced dataset. The integration of various conditions helped create a more balanced training set and improving the accuracy and reliability of severity prediction models. These studies demonstrate the importance of using DGMs to generate anomaly data, which helps address the imbalanced data problem and improves the robustness of traffic management and safety systems.

3.1.2¬†¬†¬†Trajectory Generation

Trajectory generation creates realistic movement patterns for vehicles and pedestrians, which is essential for developing accurate traffic simulations and urban planning tools. By leveraging DGMs, researchers can produce synthetic trajectories that mimic real-world behaviors of traffic agents, enabling more robust analysis and testing of transportation systems. These generated trajectories help understand traffic dynamics, evaluate transportation policies, and enhance infrastructure design. These trajectories can be further classified based on their scale and scope, such as micro and macro scales. Micro-scale trajectories focus on detailed, short-term movement patterns of individual agents in localized areas, like intersections, while macro-scale trajectories represent broader, long-term traffic flow across extensive road networks or regions. The classification into micro and macro scales significantly impacts their use cases, such as collision avoidance or urban planning, and determines the complexity of the problems they address.

3.1.2.1¬†¬†¬†Micro-scale Trajectory Generation

Micro-scale trajectory generation focuses on producing detailed, short-term predictions for localized areas, such as intersections or specific road segments. These trajectories are critical for applications requiring precise and immediate responses, like collision avoidance, maneuver planning in dense urban settings, and real-time navigation adjustments. Numerous studies have leveraged various DGMS to produce realistic micro-scale trajectories (Krajewski et¬†al., 2018; Ding et¬†al., 2019; Krajewski et¬†al., 2019; Gong et¬†al., 2023; Yang et¬†al., 2024). For example, Agarwal et¬†al. (2020) used normalizing flows in generating trajectories for Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) through the FlowPlan method. This approach employs a Conditional VAE (CVAE) to encode human expert trajectories into a low-dimensional latent space. A Neural Autoregressive flow (NAF) then maps this latent space to a Boltzmann distribution over the AV control space, effectively capturing complex, multimodal distributions of feasible control trajectories conditioned on the scene context. Rempe et¬†al. (2023) used a guided diffusion model to generate realistic pedestrian trajectories. The proposed model integrates with a physics-based humanoid controller, forming a closed-loop system capable of simulating large crowd movements across various scenarios. By combining the guided diffusion model with physical simulation, it accurately generates pedestrian trajectories that reflect real-world behavior. Similarly, Niedoba et¬†al. (2024) employed a diffusion-based generative model to simulate realistic traffic scenarios involving multiple interacting agents. To be more specific, it diffuses the trajectories of all agents in a scene jointly, based on past, present, or future state observations. This method allows for the creation of diverse and realistic traffic scenarios, including rare, safety-critical events. These studies highlight how DGMs can produce highly detailed and realistic micro-scale trajectories, which are essential for applications that require precise and immediate response capabilities in traffic systems.

3.1.2.2¬†¬†¬†Macro-scale Trajectory Generation

Macro-scale trajectory generation covers broad spatial and temporal scopes, including extensive areas such as entire road networks or large regions over longer periods. The trajectories are crucial for strategic planning, traffic management, and long-term behavioral analysis. By examining origin-destination pairs, travel time distributions, and overall traffic flow patterns, macro-scale trajectories provide valuable insights into larger trends and systemic issues. The information is vital for urban planning, optimizing public transportation systems, and enhancing the efficiency of traffic networks. Numerous studies have focused on generating macro-scale trajectories with conditional information based on the enhanced DGM by various deep-learning models (Chen et¬†al., 2021c, b; Zhang et¬†al., 2022b; Zhu et¬†al., 2024a; Wei et¬†al., 2024; Wang and Kankanhalli, 2024; Zhu et¬†al., 2024b). For example, Xiong et¬†al. (2023) introduced TrajSGAN, a model designed to generate human mobility trajectories for urban behavior analysis and decision-making. It integrates an attention-based generator for trajectory location prediction with a rollout module and a CNN-based discriminator to assess the spatial structure of the generated trajectories. This integration ensures that the results are realistic and semantically guided. TrajSGAN effectively reduces divergence in spatial-related metrics and can be utilized to study epidemic diffusion with high accuracy. Similarly, Choi et¬†al. (2021a) developed TrajGAIL, a GAIL framework for generating urban vehicle trajectories. The model combines the capabilities of GAIL with RNNs to learn the underlying distributions of urban vehicle trajectory data. TrajGAIL allows for the generation of synthetic vehicle trajectories that closely resemble real-world patterns, even from limited observations. Sun and Kim (2023) introduced MAGAIL-VL, a data-driven, network-wide traffic simulation framework considering both Vehicle and Link agents. Specifically, MAGAIL-VL learns the distribution of vehicle movements and link states from observed data, enabling the generation of realistic traffic scenarios across an entire network. Recently, diffusion-based models have become popular for generating macro-scale trajectories (Zhu et¬†al., 2024a; Wei et¬†al., 2024; Wang and Kankanhalli, 2024; Zhu et¬†al., 2024b). For example, Zhu et¬†al. (2024a) introduced a novel approach DiffTraj, which generates high-quality synthetic GPS trajectories using a spatial-temporal diffusion probabilistic model. DiffTraj model combines residual blocks and multi-scale feature fusion in U-Net architecture to accurately predict noise levels during the reverse denoising process, enhancing its performance in capturing complex spatial-temporal dependencies and generating realistic synthetic trajectories. Similarly, Wei et¬†al. (2024) presented Diff-RNTraj, a diffusion-based model designed to generate trajectories that are both geographically accurate and adhere to the logical constraints of the road network. The model combines a continuous diffusion framework with a pre-training strategy to manage the hybrid nature of road network-constrained trajectory data, resulting in realistic and usable synthetic trajectories. These studies highlight the diverse applications of DGMs in producing macro-scale trajectories. They provide essential tools and insights for improving transportation systems through strategic planning and management.

3.1.3¬†¬†¬†Missing Data Imputation

The missing data imputation in transportation aims to reconstruct original data XùëãXitalic_X from missing or corrupted data X^^ùëã\hat{X}over^ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG with conditional information œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï such as known historical data, geometry configuration, and external factors (X^=f‚Å¢(X,œï)^ùëãùëìùëãitalic-œï\hat{X}=f(X,\phi)over^ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG = italic_f ( italic_X , italic_œï )). This process inherently involves data generation, as it creates new values to fill gaps in existing datasets, thereby enhancing the volume and quality of data available for analysis. In traditional imputation methods, missing data is often challenging to reconstruct due to the complex spatio-temporal dependencies in traffic data, which limit the accuracy and robustness of simple statistical methods. In recent years, DGMs have become powerful tools for handling the complexities of traffic data imputation. Their ability to model the underlying distribution of traffic data enables them to generate realistic and accurate reconstructions of missing entries across various scenarios. DGMs can also integrate a wide range of conditional information, including the spatio-temporal dependencies of traffic data, to enhance imputation performance (Zhang et¬†al., 2024a; Cai et¬†al., 2023; Yang et¬†al., 2021; Zhang et¬†al., 2021c; Peng et¬†al., 2023; Shin et¬†al., 2023; Duan et¬†al., 2024; Chen et¬†al., 2022b). Traditionally, missing data has been categorized into three types: Missing Completely at Random (MCAR), Missing at Random (MAR), and Missing Not at Random (MNAR) (Lin and Tsai, 2020; Hasan et¬†al., 2021). However, the unique spatio-temporal characteristics of traffic data require a reevaluation of these categories. To address this, Chan et¬†al. (2023) proposed a new classification specifically for transportation research, dividing missing data into Fiber Missing Data, Block Missing Data, and Random Missing Data. In this paper, we adopt this updated categorization to better address the specific challenges of traffic data imputation.

3.1.3.1¬†¬†¬†Fiber Missing Data

Fiber Missing Data occurs when there is a sudden, temporary failure of data-acquisition devices, leading to gaps in data collection that can be short-term or long-term. Many advanced models have been developed to address this issue effectively (Li et¬†al., 2018; Zhang et¬†al., 2021c, b; Huang and Chen, 2022; Yuan et¬†al., 2022; Shen et¬†al., 2022; Cai et¬†al., 2023; Zhang et¬†al., 2023b; Hou et¬†al., 2023; Cai et¬†al., 2023; Li et¬†al., 2024c; Duan et¬†al., 2024; Zhang et¬†al., 2024a). For instance, Han et¬†al. (2020) developed the Content-Aware GAN (CA-GAN) to handle missing traffic data in time series. In this method, traffic data were considered as tensors to capture their spatial-temporal correlations. The CA-GAN learns to generate realistic traffic patterns, effectively completing gaps in speed data. Similarly, Xu et¬†al. (2021) introduced the Graph Aggregate GAN (GA-GAN), which combines the strengths of Graph Sample and Aggregate (GraphSAGE) with a GAN to impute missing traffic speed data. GraphSAGE aggregates information from neighboring nodes in the road network to capture spatial-temporal correlations, which are then used by a Wasserstein GAN (WGAN) to generate the missing data. The GA-GAN has been tested in both fiber and random missing data environments, demonstrating its versatility. Zhang et¬†al. (2021b) proposed the Gated GAN (GaGAN) to address missing speed data on signalized roads. GaGAN incorporates attention mechanisms into graph convolutional operations and GRUs to learn spatio-temporal correlations within each signal cycle. This approach is effective for both fiber and random missing data scenarios. In another study, Liu et¬†al. (2023) introduced PriSTI, a conditional diffusion framework for spatio-temporal data imputation. Specifically, the PriSTI uses a diffusion-based noise estimation module and a spatio-temporal feature extraction process to enhance its performance under high missing rates and diverse spatial configurations. It has been evaluated in environments with both fiber and random missing data, showing significant robustness. These models demonstrate the capabilities of DGMs in addressing the challenges posed by fiber missing data, ensuring the continuity and quality of traffic datasets even in the face of temporary data collection failures.

3.1.3.2¬†¬†¬†Block Missing Data

Block Missing Data occurs when there are no data-acquisition detectors in the area of interest, leading to complete loss in the dataset for the region. This type of missing data is particularly challenging to address because of the absence of any observations over an extended spatial and temporal range. Advanced DGMs have been developed to tackle this challenge, though most studies do not focus exclusively on block missing data. Instead, they often evaluate model performance under various conditions, including fiber and random missing data scenarios (Li et¬†al., 2018; Zhang et¬†al., 2021c; Yuan et¬†al., 2022; Hou et¬†al., 2023; Li et¬†al., 2023b; Zhang et¬†al., 2024a). For example, Yuan et¬†al. (2022) enhanced the performance of GAN in traffic flow imputation by designing generative and center losses. This approach was evaluated across all three types of missing data environments: Fiber, Block, and Random Missing Data. The proposed method demonstrated significant improvements in imputing missing traffic data under these conditions. In another study, Li et¬†al. (2018) combined a 3D Convolutional Neural Network with GAN (3wwDConvGAN) to address missing traffic data. Unlike traditional methods that may not fully exploit the spatial-temporal features of historical data, 3DConvGAN uses a fractional strided 3D CNN in both the generator and discriminator to enhance imputation performance. The model‚Äôs effectiveness was also tested in environments with Fiber, Block, and Random Missing Data, highlighting its versatility. Zhang et¬†al. (2021c) introduced SA-GAIN, a Self-Attention Generative Adversarial Imputation Network, designed to impute missing traffic flow data. By incorporating a self-attention mechanism in GAN, SA-GAIN effectively captures important features across spatial and temporal dimensions. The model was tested in both fiber and block missing data scenarios, demonstrating robust performance. Hou et¬†al. (2023) developed MissII, a model that combines spatial interaction models with GANs for traffic data imputation. This method first estimates traffic flow using theory-guided models that leverage environmental and social factors to capture complex traffic dynamics.
