bold_italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( square-root start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG 1 - over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_œµ , italic_t ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] + italic_C . end_CELL end_ROW (A.16)

Appendix B Derivation for Score-based Generative Model

Once the score network is trained, data generation can be accomplished through an iterative method known as Langevin dynamics, or Langevin Monte Carlo (Parisi, 1981; Grenander and Miller, 1994). Langevin dynamics is originally formulated to describe the behavior of molecular systems, such as Brownian motion. The fundamental principle of Langevin dynamics in the context of Brownian motion is captured by the Langevin Equation, which is expressed as follows:

m‚Å¢x¬®=‚àíŒª‚Å¢xÀô+Œ∑,ùëö¬®ùë•ùúÜÀôùë•ùúÇ\begin{split}m\ddot{x}=-\lambda\dot{x}+\eta\end{split},start_ROW start_CELL italic_m over¬® start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = - italic_Œª overÀô start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + italic_Œ∑ end_CELL end_ROW , (B.1)

where mùëömitalic_m is the mass of the particle, ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª is the damping coefficient, and Œ∑‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0,2‚Å¢œÉ2)similar-toùúÇùí©02superscriptùúé2\eta\sim\mathcal{N}(0,2\sigma^{2})italic_Œ∑ ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 , 2 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a Gaussian noise.

The dynamics of Brownian motion as described in Equation¬†(B.1) can be further derived by considering the potential energy in the system. Specifically, the force acting on a particle can be expressed in terms of the gradient of potential energy; i.e., ‚àÇV‚Å¢(x)‚àÇx=‚àáV‚Å¢(x)ùëâùë•ùë•‚àáùëâùë•\frac{\partial V(x)}{\partial x}=\nabla V(x)divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_V ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_x end_ARG = ‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ). This leads to a reformulation of the equation as:

‚àáV‚Å¢(x)=‚àíŒª‚Å¢xÀô+Œ∑,‚àáùëâùë•ùúÜÀôùë•ùúÇ\nabla V(x)=-\lambda\dot{x}+\eta,‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) = - italic_Œª overÀô start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + italic_Œ∑ , (B.2)

or equivalently,

Œª‚Å¢xÀô=‚àí‚àáV‚Å¢(x)+Œ∑.ùúÜÀôùë•‚àáùëâùë•ùúÇ\lambda\dot{x}=-\nabla V(x)+\eta.italic_Œª overÀô start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = - ‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) + italic_Œ∑ . (B.3)

This relationship allows us to interpret the motion of the particle in terms of potential energy changes, where ‚àí‚àáV‚Å¢(x)‚àáùëâùë•-\nabla V(x)- ‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) represents the deterministic force derived from the potential energy landscape and Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ accounts for stochastic thermal fluctuations. To capture these dynamics in a more mathematically rigorous framework suitable for simulation and analysis, we can transform this physical concept into a stochastic differential equation (SDE):

d‚Å¢x=‚àí‚àáV‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢d‚Å¢t+2‚Å¢œÉ‚Å¢d‚Å¢W,ùëëùë•‚àáùëâùë•ùëëùë°2ùúéùëëùëädx=-\nabla V(x)dt+\sqrt{2}\sigma dW,italic_d italic_x = - ‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_t + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_œÉ italic_d italic_W , (B.4)

where the term ‚àí‚àáV‚Å¢(x)‚àáùëâùë•-\nabla V(x)- ‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) is the drift term, which guides the particle towards lower potential energy states, thus simulating deterministic motion under the influence of forces. The term 2‚Å¢œÉ‚Å¢d‚Å¢W2ùúéùëëùëä\sqrt{2}\sigma dWsquare-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_œÉ italic_d italic_W represents the stochastic component of the motion, with œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ being the volatility (akin to the temperature in physical systems) and d‚Å¢WùëëùëädWitalic_d italic_W denoting the derivative of a standard Wiener process, which models the random thermal fluctuations.

In the context of probability distributions, the stochastic process described in Equation¬†(B.4) corresponds to a Fokker-Planck equation (Fokker, 1914; Planck, 1917; Kadanoff, 2000) for the probability density function p‚Å¢(x,t)ùëùùë•ùë°p(x,t)italic_p ( italic_x , italic_t ) of finding the system in state xùë•xitalic_x at time tùë°titalic_t:

‚àÇ‚àÇt‚Å¢p‚Å¢(x,t)=‚àá‚ãÖ[‚àáV‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢p‚Å¢(x,t)+œÉ2‚Å¢‚àáp‚Å¢(x,t)].ùë°ùëùùë•ùë°‚ãÖ‚àádelimited-[]‚àáùëâùë•ùëùùë•ùë°superscriptùúé2‚àáùëùùë•ùë°\frac{\partial}{\partial t}p(x,t)=\nabla\cdot\left[\nabla V(x)p(x,t)+\sigma^{2% }\nabla p(x,t)\right].divide start_ARG ‚àÇ end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_t end_ARG italic_p ( italic_x , italic_t ) = ‚àá ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) italic_p ( italic_x , italic_t ) + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá italic_p ( italic_x , italic_t ) ] . (B.5)

At steady state, the time derivative of the probability density function becomes zero, implying:

0=‚àá‚ãÖ[‚àáV‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢p‚Å¢(x,t)+œÉ2‚Å¢‚àáp‚Å¢(x,t)],0‚ãÖ‚àádelimited-[]‚àáùëâùë•ùëùùë•ùë°superscriptùúé2‚àáùëùùë•ùë°0=\nabla\cdot\left[\nabla V(x)p(x,t)+\sigma^{2}\nabla p(x,t)\right],0 = ‚àá ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) italic_p ( italic_x , italic_t ) + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá italic_p ( italic_x , italic_t ) ] , (B.6)

which simplifies to:

‚àáV‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢p‚Å¢(x)=‚àíœÉ2‚Å¢‚àáp‚Å¢(x,t).‚àáùëâùë•ùëùùë•superscriptùúé2‚àáùëùùë•ùë°\nabla V(x)p(x)=-\sigma^{2}\nabla p(x,t).‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) italic_p ( italic_x ) = - italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá italic_p ( italic_x , italic_t ) . (B.7)

Dividing both sides by p‚Å¢(x)ùëùùë•p(x)italic_p ( italic_x ) and rearranging gives:

‚àáV‚Å¢(x)‚àù‚àí‚àáp‚Å¢(x,t)p‚Å¢(x)=‚àí‚àálog‚Å°p‚Å¢(x),proportional-to‚àáùëâùë•‚àáùëùùë•ùë°ùëùùë•‚àáùëùùë•\nabla V(x)\propto-\frac{\nabla p(x,t)}{p(x)}=-\nabla\log p(x),‚àá italic_V ( italic_x ) ‚àù - divide start_ARG ‚àá italic_p ( italic_x , italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_x ) end_ARG = - ‚àá roman_log italic_p ( italic_x ) , (B.8)

indicating that, at equilibrium, the gradient of the potential energy is proportional to the gradient of the log of the probability distribution. This equilibrium condition underlies the principle that in a score-based generative model, the score function ‚àáùê±log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)subscript‚àáùê±ùëùùê±\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log p(\mathbf{x})‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ) can be interpreted as akin to a force derived from a potential energy landscape, guiding the generation process towards high-probability regions of the data distribution.

Therefore, Equation¬†(B.4) can be re-written as:

d‚Å¢x=‚àálog‚Å°p‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢d‚Å¢t+2‚Å¢œÉ‚Å¢d‚Å¢W,ùëëùë•‚àáùëùùë•ùëëùë°2ùúéùëëùëädx=\nabla\log p(x)dt+\sqrt{2}\sigma dW,italic_d italic_x = ‚àá roman_log italic_p ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_t + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_œÉ italic_d italic_W , (B.9)

To implement this in a discrete setting for numerical simulation or data generation, the SDE can be approximated as follows:

ùê±i+1‚Üêùê±i+‚àáxlog‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)‚Å¢œµ+2‚Å¢œÉ‚Å¢Œî‚Å¢W,‚Üêsubscriptùê±ùëñ1subscriptùê±ùëñsubscript‚àáùë•ùëùùê±italic-œµ2ùúéŒîùëä\mathbf{x}_{i+1}\leftarrow\mathbf{x}_{i}+\nabla_{x}\log p(\mathbf{x})\epsilon+% \sqrt{2}\sigma\Delta W,bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üê bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ) italic_œµ + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_œÉ roman_Œî italic_W , (B.10)

where œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ is a small timestep, and Œî‚Å¢W‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0,œµ)similar-toŒîùëäùí©0italic-œµ\Delta W\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\epsilon)roman_Œî italic_W ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_œµ ) represents a discrete approximation of the Wiener process increment. Thus, it can be further simplified as:

ùê±i+1‚Üêùê±i+‚àáxlog‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê±)‚ãÖœµ+2‚Å¢œµ‚ãÖùê≥i,‚Üêsubscriptùê±ùëñ1subscriptùê±ùëñ‚ãÖsubscript‚àáùë•ùëùùê±italic-œµ‚ãÖ2italic-œµsubscriptùê≥ùëñ\mathbf{x}_{i+1}\leftarrow\mathbf{x}_{i}+\nabla_{x}\log p(\mathbf{x})\cdot% \epsilon+\sqrt{2\epsilon}\cdot\mathbf{z}_{i},bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üê bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ) ‚ãÖ italic_œµ + square-root start_ARG 2 italic_œµ end_ARG ‚ãÖ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (B.11)

where ùê≥i‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0,I)similar-tosubscriptùê≥ùëñùí©0ùêº\mathbf{z}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I)bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I ).
